header_1: H5N1 in Wild birds in UK
content_1: Bird flu has been ruled out as a cause of death in seven swans on the Seiont River. The swans died on June 11 near the Aber Swing Bridge, Caernarfon, over 300 miles from a swannery in Abbotsbury where 11 birds died of avian influenza beginning in January, and 200 miles from a June 3rd avian influenza outbreak in Oxfordshire. Tests have ruled out bird flu, but the exact cause of death has not yet been determined.
content_2: Avian influenza has been reported in ducks in the Guangdong province. Though the actual outbreak date where 3,873 ducks died has not been released, another 17,127 ducks were culled after H5N1 was detected on June 13th.Â  Guangdong province is in southern China, adjacent to Hong Kong, where an outbreak in poultry markets led to large-scale culling last week. The affected farm does not supply poultry to Hong Kong, but a farm, located less than 10 km away, is a confirmed supplier to the market.
content_3: In Quang Ngai province, 690 chickens died of avian influenza at a small household farm. Quang Ngai is one of two provinces in Vietnam to be affected by bird flu, the other is Tra Vinh.
header_4: H5N1 in Humans in Hong Kong
content_4: A Hygiene Department contractor who reported flu-like symptoms in Hong Kong has been cleared of being infected with avian influenza.  The man was hired to help clean the Po On Road market after H5N1 was found in three of the seven market stalls in early June.  He developed a fever and respiratory symptoms, but has tested negative for H5N1, and appears to have influenza B.
